properties.name: Paddle Battle
properties.description: Based on the classic game Pong, Paddle Battle is a simple multiplayer game where two players compete to bounce a ball off their paddle.

objects.name: Instructions_Text
objects.string: Use arrow keys or gamepad to move paddle

content.text: Use arrow keys or gamepad to move paddle

events.comment: Force players to join a lobby game
Show the player number that was assigned
Stick text to paddles
Pick a random starting angle for the ball
Each player controls their own paddle

events.name: Make Acceleration include Deceleration when moving in the opposite direction
Make Acceleration include Deceleration when moving in the opposite direction
Slowly boost the speed of the ball when it hits a player paddle

events.comment: Prevent player paddles from going through walls
Bounce the ball off walls
Player 1 scored
Player 2 scored

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SpriteMultitouchJoystick
description: Multitouch joysticks are objects showing a joystick on the screen, useful for mobile. They work like a physical gamepad:
- 4 or 8 directions
- Analogus pads
- Player selection

- Automatic "mapper" behaviors for 2D and 3D movement behaviors (platformer characters, top-down movement, 3D character etc...). Add one of these to the object with the movement behavior (i.e: the player most of the time) and the behavior will then be controlled automatically by the virtual joystick (it works by reading the multitouch joystick state and simulating controls). No need for additional events to make it work once the behaviors are set up.
There are ready-to-use joysticks in the asset-store [multitouch joysticks pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=multitouch-joysticks-multitouch-joysticks).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Sticker
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Make objects follow the position and rotation of the object they are stuck to.
description: This extension can be useful to:
- Stick accessories to moving objects
- Animate a skeleton
- Delete an object with another one
An example allows to check it out ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://stick-objects)).

eventsFunctions.description: Define helper classes JavaScript code.
eventsFunctions.name: DefineHelperClasses

inlineCode: * Update the coordinates in the basisObject basis.
* It uses the basisObject coordinates from the previous frame.
* This way, the sticker can move relatively to it and still
// Save initial values to avoid calculus and rounding errors
* Copy the coordinates to use it the next frame.
* This method is also called by children to ensure
// If the behavior on the basis object has a different name,
// the objects will still follow their basis objects
// Follow parents 1st to avoid frame delays
// Unproportional dimensions changes won't work as expected
// if the object angle is not null but nothing more can be done
// because there is no full affine transformation on objects.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Bounce
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Bounce the object off another object it just touched.
description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched.
>  This *won't work* with Physics engine or Platformer characters. This is working with objects that are moved using actions or behaviors using **the forces**.
The Breakout-like example uses this extension to make balls bounce ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://breakout)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Bounce

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOff

events.comment:
To bounce the object realistically, we first separate it from the obstacle. The collision engine will do it by moving the object through the shortest "normal vector" of the edge that was collided.
We store the position of the object before being moved so that we know the angle of this "normal vector". Once we know it, we add a force in the direction of the normal vector, and we add the difference between the normal vector and the previous angle of movement.

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be calculated *to go toward the specified angle (the "normal angle")*. For example, if the object is arriving at this exact angle, it will bounce in the opposite direction.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Bounce off another object toward a specified angle
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffSpecificAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Bounce _PARAM0_ off _PARAM2_ assuming a normal angle of _PARAM3_

events.comment:
Check if there is a collision between the object and an obstacle and if so, do the bounce by stopping the object and adding a force so that it goes in the "reflected" direction, using the "normal" angle provided. 
This provides a realistic bounce.

parameters.description: The "normal" angle, in degrees, to bounce against
parameters.longDescription: This can be understood at the direction that the bounce must go toward.
parameters.name: NormalAngle

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be vertical, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly horizontal obstacle* (like the top/bottom of the screen in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 90 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: -90 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffVertically

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be horizontal, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly vertical obstacle* (like paddles in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 0 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: 180 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffHorizontally

eventsFunctions.description: the number of times this object has bounced off another object.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceCount

propertyDescriptors.label: Bounce count
propertyDescriptors.description: Number of times this object has bounced off another object
propertyDescriptors.name: BounceCount

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Gamepads
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, trigger pressure, etc...
description: Add support for gamepads (or other physical controllers).
It gives access to:
- button presses,
- axis positions and force,
- trigger pressure,
- configurable deadzone,
- vibration,

- automatic "gamepad mapper" behaviors for 2D and 3D movement behaviors (platformer characters, top-down movement, 3D character etc...). Add one of these to the object with the movement behavior (i.e: the player most of the time) and the behavior will then be controlled automatically by the gamepad (it works by reading the gamepad state and simulating controls). No need for additional events to make it work once the behaviors are set up.
The Bomberman-like example handles 4 players with gamepads ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://goose-bomberman)).

eventsFunctions.description: Check if a gamepad is connected.
eventsFunctions.name: C_Controller_X_is_connected

inlineCode: // If gamepad was disconnected it will be null (so this will return false)
// If gamepad was never connected it will be undefined (so this will return false)

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a vibration on the specified controller. Might only work if the game is running in a recent web browser.
eventsFunctions.name: A_Vibrate_controller

inlineCode: //Vibration work only on game in browser.

parameters.description: Time of the vibration, in seconds (optional, default value is 1)
parameters.name: Duration

eventsFunctions.description: Generate an advanced vibration on the specified controller. Incompatible with Firefox.
eventsFunctions.name: A_Advanced_Vibration_Controller
eventsFunctions.sentence: Make gamepad _PARAM1_ vibrate for _PARAM2_ seconds with the vibration magnitude of _PARAM3_ and _PARAM4_

inlineCode: //Vibration work only on game in browser.

parameters.description: Time of the vibration, in seconds (optional, default value is 1)
parameters.name: Duration

eventsFunctions.description: Change a vibration on the specified controller. Incompatible with Firefox.
eventsFunctions.name: A_Change_Vibration_Magnitude
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the vibration magnitude of _PARAM2_ & _PARAM3_ on gamepad _PARAM1_

inlineCode: //Vibration work only on game in browser.

eventsFunctions.description: Check if any button is released on a gamepad.
eventsFunctions.name: C_any_button_released
eventsFunctions.sentence: Any button of gamepad _PARAM1_ is released

eventsFunctions.description: Return the strength of the weak vibration motor on the gamepad of a player.
eventsFunctions.name: WeakVibrationMagnitude

eventsFunctions.description: Return the strength of the strong vibration motor on the gamepad of a player.
eventsFunctions.name: StrongVibrationMagnitude

parameters: Gamepads::AcceleratedSpeed(CurrentRotationSpeedZ, Gamepads::StickForceX(GamepadIdentifier, CameraStick) * HorizontalRotationSpeedMax, HorizontalRotationSpeedMax, HorizontalRotationAcceleration, HorizontalRotationDeceleration)

Gamepads::AcceleratedSpeed(CurrentRotationSpeedY, Gamepads::StickForceY(GamepadIdentifier, CameraStick) * VerticalRotationSpeedMax, VerticalRotationSpeedMax, VerticalRotationAcceleration, VerticalRotationDeceleration)

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera to look though _PARAM1_ eyes. The object must look to the right when all its angles are 0 and the top of its head be toward Z+.
eventsFunctions.group: Layers and cameras
eventsFunctions.name: LookFromObjectEyes
eventsFunctions.sentence: Move the camera to look though _PARAM0_ eyes
